to build a resilient & flexible system, you need iteration. it’s inevitable. a system can only prove its value when exposed to multiple different contexts. if it fails to adapt to a new context, it’s not a great system yet. as you iterate on multiple contexts, the system will progressively adapt to cover more edge cases, and patterns will start to emerge naturally. this takes time, effort and refactoring – you have to put in the work & not be afraid to break things in the process

sometimes I wonder if value-for-value was the main pricing model. i.e. pay what you want – buyer sets the price instead of seller. if the value is created through the lens of the customer – would this push businesses to offer better products & services? it’s also really common for a buyer to overrate the value of something right after experiencing it, or using it for the first time. this means profit for the seller – win-win situation

folder-based structures are possibly the most inefficient way to organize digital knowledge. expensive to navigate, as you need to go through each & every layer. risk of duplication, as a file can exist in multiple folders with no global visibility. mentally taxing to work out when working with other people – everyone conceptualizes information layers differently. flat structures may seem chaotic at first, but they’re the way to go. auto-generated keywords & taxonomies can help fast discovery, and provide a passive way to organize knowledge with little active input required. only input needed is a search query – everything else works behind the scenes. a robust, well-implemented search will beat folder-based structures any day of the week
accept things you can’t change. take action when you can change things

biggest pain point in diagramming is worrying about low-level, visual design decisions. i propose a diagramming tool that is extremely opinionated about these decisions. prevent me from spending useless time arranging nodes & connections, layout, spacing, sizing. every element falls into a predefined grid. user interaction is minimal – add, edit, delete. no pixel pushing allowed. this is the only way to make the user employ conceptual, high-level thinking

realizing i spent a lot of time learning music the wrong way. a lot of teaching is focused on giving you highly applicable snippets: cool chords, pentatonic scales, neo-soul progressions. you memorize these snippets for one song, one context; and you’re unable export that knowledge elsewhere. this is the wrong way. the right way is conceptual relations first: how each chord functions in a progression, how each note functions in a chord. high-level abstraction, over knowing what finger goes on what key/fret

the more low-level customization a product has, the less efficient it is. giving freedom to your users is not about letting me change colors, fonts, etc. it’s about getting the task done. to get a task done, you have to guide their focus to the meaningful, impactful actions. be opinionated about the non-relevant details. liberate users to think about what is relevant. less customization leads to more focus. you want to give focus, not freedom

calling someone by a wrong name is so careless. it feels dismissive, shows lack of respect. your name is something very personal, it's very tied to your sense of self. not remembering it feels like a subtle way of saying you’re not important enough to remember.
every time it's voting day I like to watch people and guess who they’re going to vote for. i would say i get it right 80% of the time, but i will never know
to get great feedback, ask 3 questions: is this directionally correct? what might be missing? where we push it further?

if a society is tolerant without limit, their ability to be tolerant will eventually be destroyed by the intolerant. therefore, in order to maintain a tolerant society, the society must be intolerant of intolerance

if you want people to provide ideas, you need to provide the structure. people won’t be proactive without direction. they need to know the boundaries. as a leader, you define the boundaries, and build the sandbox. you make clear what is the goal — but without prescribing the journey
the process of making art is the art

what seems complex is often just unfamiliar. it’s just a label for something we don't understand. complexity complexity is only but a byproduct of misunderstanding. if you understand something, it ceases to be complex
if anything, LLM assistants enabled me to ask questions without the fear of being judged. i could get answers through a human — but I could never ask the same questions to a human
all that we perceive, all our awareness, all knowledge must come through the senses
solving boredom with consumption robs you of the chance to solve it with creation
clear beats clever. clever feels smart now but dumb later. clear feels dumb now but smart later

being intentional about your guilty pleasures is a good thing. having ownership over the things that entertain you. don't just be passive to pleasure — be intentional on the moments you want to get it

software is the most practical & thoughtful gift you can give someone. it packs so much utilitarian value. wonder why it’s rarely considered as a gift. maybe because it’s not tangible. but software is often the digital extension of who we are, shaping our behavior & thinking, daily. so let’s normalize gifting app subscriptions to our best friends

expertise can’t be achieved by performing in ideal conditions. ideal conditions are statistical outliers. a very small subset of real-world scenarios. if you build your knowledge on a fraction of reality, you fail to build strong pattern recognition. you become unaware of complexity — and when it eventually creeps in, you don’t know the escape routes. so, to be an expert, you have to rehearse failure. you need exposure to edge cases, and strategize contingency when things fail. because they will
i’m incapable of gifting something i wouldn’t like to be gifted myself. i think that’s a good rule
too many people are afraid of being weird. so when you finally find someone with no filters, you get deeply attached to their energy
adding the first emoji reaction is the digital equivalent to being the first one to clap
a long night out is never worth the value of an early morning
life is about introducing chaos while regulating entropy

people say you should act like no one’s watching. i think the opposite — you should act like everyone’s watching. perform yourself. be your own audience. you will ease your way into external judgement, if you already went through it internally
create like a child & edit like a scientist

sometimes it’s best to be good enough. i’m wired to maximize — if i start something, i want to get really good at it. but is it worth it? there’s an opportunity cost in mastery. for the same time & energy you put into it, you get diminishing returns in growth. the curve flattens. it does feel uncomfortable to leave things “unfinished”, and there’s inertia to sunk cost. but it’s strategic incompletion — leaving at the inflection point of return vs. investment

you must have your own projects. something that belongs to you, only. not having to convince anyone of anything is a blessing. no stakeholders, no pitches, no meetings — your own judgment & taste is all that matters. no metrics, just vibes. no waiting for permission, full freedom to ship. whatever you want. as long as it’s beautiful
to make AI good, get good yourself. AI is a multiplier. if you’re a small coefficient, you won’t see much gain. if you’re a negative coefficient, expect negative gains

feels dystopian to have AI giving you better advice than a friend. a friend will try to comfort you, take your side, or be afraid of going against your opinion. an LLM is logical & neutral. it has no feelings, so it can be objectively honest. and you can be honest too, without judgment

in a world where anyone can create anything, most won’t. to be able to create anything is too much choice. which is its own kind of friction. most of us don’t want infinite freedom, we want a strong opinion to follow

do i deserve to please myself? or is the pleasure i seek just a quick fix for existential discomfort? easy to fall into a form of escapist hedonism, if you’re seeking pleasure without purpose. but i think pleasure can have purpose — if it flows from achieving something meaningful. finishing a project, earning a promotion, pushing through a hard workout. pleasure carries value if it’s earned from pain. pleasure as a reward for effort

it’s really hard not to be divergent if you’re intelligent. once you’ve formed a wide enough map of ideas, once you’ve collected all these dots from different places, it’s difficult to try to force them into one straight line. there’s this constant pull — your brain just doesn’t want to commit to a single path because it knows there are other valid ones

i stick with the default. i don’t like to customize. there’s a sense of comfort in leaving things as they are. i get anxious when altering the original, intended experience. staying with the default also helps me focus on what matters — the experience itself. related: people usually overrate their own taste. so they customize too early, instead of giving a chance to the original experience. a naive (maybe arrogant) pride in having something unique
if you’re not interested, you’re not interesting. curiosity is charisma. magnetize people by leading with curiosity

common mistake when learning something new is getting good the wrong way. if you take shortcuts, pick up hacks, you get decent fast. but you never get beyond that. because what you skipped becomes what holds you back. you hit the ceiling too early. and by the time you realize it, unlearning is harder than learning ever was
living an emotional pendulum — between wanting someone to love you, or having someone you want to love
return something in better condition than you found it applies to people too
trying something new doesn’t mean you’re becoming someone else. instead, it’s how you find who you really are. you need the contrast of something unfamiliar to sharpen your own identity
success = obsession + focus
working out is a non-negotiable habit. it is not a hobby. it is not a choice. it’s something you do because you have a body. a basic human requirement. like sleep. like water
a friend is someone you can text in lowercase

never say yes on the spot. commitments don’t feel dangerous, but they are. a casual “why not” becomes a weekend you didn’t want. an impulsive “let’s do it” becomes a project you don’t have time for. saying no doesn’t help either. people will ask why, negotiate, debate, persuade. the trick is to delay the response. make space to think, avoid making decisions on instinct. be immune to the social expectation of an immediate yes. it’s not indecision — it’s reflection
our beliefs are informed by people more than facts. we agree with people we like, despite the facts. it’s easier to believe a lie from someone you like, than the truth from someone you dislike

crazy is to not be crazy. fight the inertia that you call safety. don’t be afraid to “fail”. unhinged or nothing. inertia feels invisible until you try to break it. it’a only until you do different, that you feel the drag.

memory isn’t one thing. there is memory for doing, and memory for feeling — prospective memory, and episodic memory. prospective is short-term, working memory on remembering to carry out an intention (e.g. pick up groceries on the way home). episodic is long-term, sensorial memory on recalling specific events in rich detail (e.g. a summer afternoon from 12 years ago). episodic memory is sticky — the amygdala adds emotional weight to it, and your brain evolved to remember high-emotion moments. prospective memory is fragile — highly dependent on attention, and it fades without executive function
what you do speaks so loudly, i can’t hear what you say

we’ve normalized overconsumption. eating while watching YouTube. going for a walk while listening to music. going to the toilet while scrolling reels. there’s no breathing room for the mind, instead it’s a never-ending stream of dopamine. how do we expect to create something great, if we all we do is consume?

i keep ignoring the hidden cost of ownership. latest example: the dilemma of renting vs. owning a surfboard. it’s easy to compare a rental price vs. purchase price of a surfboard, by looking at the break-even point. after 15 surfing sessions, owning the surfboard is cheaper than renting it. but the “invisible” part — the space, maintenance, flexibility — often matters just as much. you need to keep the surfboard. you need to store it, you need to clean it, you need to transport it, maybe repair it, and eventually sell it. the mental overhead of owning the surfboard, justifies the decision to rent it — far beyond the break-even point. lesson is: it’s often better to rent the benefit, than to own the burden

why do we take photos of sunsets? the sun will set every day. it’s predictable, ordinary. it’s impersonal — it says nothing about you. prefer people over landscapes — a sunset won’t remember you back, but a friend will
drinking from glass is sensorially better than plastic. the mouth feel is different. cold drinks feel colder. taste perception is pure. materials matter as much as liquids
you don’t burn out from working hard. you burn out from working on things you don’t believe in. if work aligns with your values, if you feel purpose & agency, you get energized
walking into your room at night and seeing a neatly folded bed waiting for you. making your bed is a daily gift you leave for your future self

transcendent thinking. your ability live through a situation, analyze the underlying dynamics, and extract a broader heuristic that transcends the original domain. it’s a form of inductive reasoning — going from specific → general, concrete → abstract
the price of community is inconvenience
social media is just e-commerce in disguise

there is something about moving through space. traveling to a place, taking a train or a flight, shifts my mind into thinking mode. fuzzy thoughts surface and become clear ideas. brain fog evaporates. attention span expands. thoughts become slow & deep, instead of fast & reactive
value is inversely proportional to abundance

it’s easy to fall into living on ephemeral knowledge. daily news, latest trending stories — short-lived, urgent information. gives you the illusion of being informed, staying on top of what’s happening. but doesn’t compound into lasting insight about anything. you have to get away from the noise, to have room for cultivating persistent knowledge. focus your attention on high-leverage, portable knowledge, systems, principles, and patterns
living by yourself should be a prerequisite to living with someone else
some things are only hard because you fail to not fear them. if you eliminate fear you become good. the whole point of being good is not fearing. e.g. diving, surfing

price creates homophily. it filters people by financial investment, which correlates with lifestyle & culture preferences. you’re around people “like you” — people who spend similarly often share priorities on what matters

you can leverage AI to generate abundance & variation. get diversity of perspectives, options to choose from. but you must stay in control of the output, and decide on what resonates with you. if you let AI take the decision, you lose control. you get overwhelmed by output that is not yours, and ultimately become disconnected — the output doesn’t resonate

we often reject optimization for things that are supposed to be magical — like romance, finding a partner. we romanticize inefficiency, being effortless, because putting in the effort will contaminate something that is pure

you are looking, but are you really seeing? so much of what meets my eyes, doesn’t meet my mind. wandering, thinking about the past & future, instead of observing the present moment. but it’s hard to feel compelled to see, if everything you look at is a repetition. the same road, the same neighborhood, the same birds, the same trees. i’m craving novelty. to see again

being so rigid about alcohol consumption is unhealthy. we ignore how chronic stress, social isolation, and the anxiety of constantly optimizing every health metric probably does more damage than a few drinks per week. feeling guilty about every minor indulgence. meta-stress of health perfectionism might be the most overlooked epidemic of our time

the reason you lack time is you’re not putting focused effort on what you do. if you put in a half-assed effort, you will get a quarter of the results. what should take 30 minutes, takes 2 hours — which indeed you might not have time for

free speech is a self-defeating ideal. if all speech is free, hatred perpetrates. racism, sexism, homophobia. all are spread via “free” speech. but they cause so many people to lose their freedom of individuality. if everyone is free to say what they want, no one is free to be who they want. it’s repressive tolerance

the art of exploration lies in resisting premature precision. not getting stuck in the details too early, and being comfortable with imperfect outputs. every low-level decision pulls you out of the creative flow. you have to optimize for abundance & variety, instead of perfection & polish
it’s easier to steer a moving ship than one that’s sitting still

what you do in private always shows in public. reading shows in conversations. your workouts show in your physique. your diet shows in your energy. your discipline shows in your confidence. your focus shows in your results. you are what you cultivate when no one is watching
maintain intellectual courage. don’t collapse into consensus

it feels dystopian to seek life advice from an LLM. but in reality, an LLM is a great way to get neutral, unbiased, insightful advice. humans are getting so emotionally distant. so overstimulated and tired. so afraid to touch feelings. but maybe i’m not surrounded by the right humans
inverse relationship between how loud you are and how substantial is what you have to say
you need to have a person in your life who is your example of how to be. someone so consistently rational & moral, that whenever you’re facing a decision you think: “what would {person} do?”

perfect doesn’t exist. the perfect home doesn’t exist. the perfect partner doesn’t exist. but should i settle for less? or should i believe i deserve better? the grass is always greener. there’s always something better. until there isn’t. i just can’t wait forever for something that doesn’t exist
when you focus on your past instead of your future, you begin to age. aging means your memories start to outweigh your dreams

small talk is good. you don’t need to speed run vulnerability. getting closer needs time & repetition. tell me about the weather and how you love the sun. and then on our 10th time talking about the sun, maybe we can talk about when it rains, too
averaging opinions leads to average results

loving someone is believing in their underlying goodness. choosing to look past their mistakes, bad days, erratic moments — and seeing someone essentially good. it’s challenging, because you have to maintain a distinction between the person & the behavior, their core values & their current expression. but if you feel the underlying goodness, it’s easy to fall in love

do i actually love the person, or do i just want the person to love me? this is a recurring issue in my romantic relationships — i’m performing a version of myself designed to generate desire. behaviors that look like love & interest — spending time together, doing acts of service, saying words of affections  — all have a selfish, egocentric motivation. of being wanted. which is dishonest, exhausting, and ultimately unfulfilling for both sides. when that initial validation is secured, i’m left with a person who loves me for who i can’t be. i’ve used them. even if not malicious, it’s deceptive. and it always ends up in pain
the flower opens to the sun knowing the clouds will come. the flower does not know if it will rain or shine. but a closed flower never grows
to have taste, you must taste. experience what feels good, and what doesn’t feel so good. understand why. curate and seek

choose to be a beginner. not once. but again & again. the humiliation of not knowing the basics, the stress of starting from zero. it’s what keeps you humble. it’s where you grow. you avoid it because it’s uncomfortable, but discomfort is the point. let yourself be bad at it. competence makes you rigid. being bad at something new cracks you open
your brain needs sensory detail to stay in your body, not in your head. focus on what feels good to you. sensation over performance. never skip your own pleasure
being the best is not a destination. it’s a checkpoint. a transient state of satisfaction, followed by inner desire to move upwards — to something bigger & better
maintaining optionality is costly, because by delaying commitment, you miss out on compounding

popularity is often not the right proxy of quality. it all depends on the people/consumers — they are the lowest common denominator. if the audience is low-quality, the most popular thing is low-quality
action produces information. information produces clarity. clarity produces better action. if there’s no major downside that can’t be reversed → act
being present in the moment feels like unblurring your senses

i’ve learned that it’s not so good to be a chameleon. being too flexible & adaptable will get into situations that don’t fit you. you try to be everything & please everyone, performing multiple versions of yourself, without understanding who you actually are
lowercase text is written sprezzatura

attachment is caused by scarcity. you become attached when something essential feels in short supply: like love, money, a job, a friend. in contrast, if you live in abundance, with a set of options available, you become less attached — increasing your psychological freedom. abundance doesn’t eliminate attachment; it simply makes it more voluntary, less fear-driven

sampling as much as you can to understand what works & what doesn’t, and why. having great taste isn’t just knowing that food is good. it’s knowing whether or not it needs a bit more salt. and the only way you can know that is if you sampled it in all variations (over salted, under salted, with side dish, with wine)
when you don’t belong, just leave. it’s not good for you. it’s not good for the people around you

the opportunities that come your way, passively, are rarely the best ones. the opportunities you actively seek out, and intentionally match with your goals/requirements, those are the ones you should fight for

some people avoid automating tasks because staying always visibly busy feels nice. low-effort, redundant work  doing recurrent, redundant tasks is, in a way, addictive given how easy they are to achieve
the fastest way for bonding is finding common relatable context. if you’re both corporate nerds, if you like the same music, if you work in the same area. leverage common context to initiate bonding
speech to text is a seriously underrated input method. if you want to get shit done, speak your thinking
collecting data about things you love is a great way to stay motivated about them
how much you daydream influences how much you night dream?
giving money as a gift is terrible. a gift shouldn’t maximize utilitarianism, instead it should be an exercise on you being present in the mind of the other person. reading what they want

you need to force yourself into getting addicted to the right things. but once you do, the good addiction will carry itself. especially in digital, where recommendation algorithms reinforce your interests
most people don’t think, they mimic. one person solves a problem, and everyone else copies the solution
if you define something too early, you limit what it could be

thinking about finishing last. in a competition, there is always someone that gets last place. is it defeat to finish last? i don’t think so. willing to be last is a strong signal of resilience. the difference between “i can’t” being the last to finish a race isn’t defeat. there must always be someone that is last. but the last person is still miles ahead of everyone who stayed out on the couch. being last is still being the only one of the ones who tried. being last is being resilient
music asks for presence. yet we throw it in the background of everything we do. driving, working, running. when music becomes background, you don’t really hear it. you consume it

short form content is not the issue. the issue is low density content. a well-crafted tweet can pack more insight than a rambling essay. you should optimize for insight per word. length should serve the density of insight

in a world of infinite output, storytelling is the moat. the ability to compress chaos into something humans can feel & remember. storytelling is the only way to impose meaning on abundance & coherence on noise

give me feedback without removing my desire of ownership. avoid being prescriptive, otherwise i become passive to please you. allow me to have an opinion. guide me through your rationale, but let me have the final decision

being so performative will kill me. at work, performing alignment with ideas i don’t believe in. in relationships, performing romantic interest to avoid a harsh break-up. both require me to constantly manage this gap between what i actually think & feel, and what i’m projecting
you can only connect with someone as deeply as you connect with yourself
what you create is the honest reflection of who you are

being delusional is how you make it. being driven by an irrational self-belief that you’re capable of something unprecedented & extraordinary, with no evidence of it being possible. and then, have the audacity to chase it, ignoring the gap between who you are now, and who you need to become to achieve it. claiming it first, then growing into it. because you’re not delusional about reality — you’re delusional about your ceiling
i’ll know i found her when she’s the only contact without a last name.

too many people fall into fundamentalism. often not because they have a narrow, close-minded view of the world. but because they equate strength of character with being always right. they view doubt as a sign of weakness. so they become too focused on defending their own psychological stagnancy. they don’t know that changing your mind is the ultimate form of intellectual honesty

the way you see the world is a self perpetuating loop. if you believe the world will accept you and co-create joy, you experience that. if you believe the world won’t accept you, you’ll feel rejection

emotional control is not same as emotional suppression. control is about reducing the half-life of reactivity. it is not about becoming apathetic, never feeling anger or frustration. it is about how long you allow that state to persist. suppressing your emotions compounds into emotional debt (which increases reactivity). small daily frustrations that are ignored, rather than processed, build a reservoir of tension. eventually, the debt becomes so high that a tiny inconvenience triggers a massive overreaction. you aren’t reacting to the event — you are reacting to the accumulated stack of emotional cache
reject worry. worry is mental motion without movement. worry is passive procrastination on uncertainty. to reduce uncertainty, take action. action is clarification through experimentation

this relentless emphasis on taking action, but often the real issue is being impatient. you’re staying restless & anxious knowing you need to do something, but also knowing you can’t do it right now. things have their own timeline, and sometimes all you can do is wait. but how do you wait? are you able to hold it in your mind & stay calm? do you capture it & let it rest in your to-do list? find your strategy. but don’t worry on what you can’t act on
winter sun is the best sun. the contrast between the cold air and the warmth of the sun light. winter sun is scarce — you don’t take it for granted. so it makes you appreciate it even more

it feels brutal to realize that the train has passed, and it’s too late to catch it. she was the perfect match — but you let her go. i was so distracted. because you didn’t have the courage to ask the hard questions. to get the honest answers. life moves on fast. lesson learned. don’t leave anything to be said. don’t leave anything to be done. if you feel it, say it. if you want it, get it
